title: Boris Pigovat
text:
Boris Pigovat (<a href="Hebrew">Hebrew</a>: בוריס פיגובט; born 1953 in <a href="Odessa">Odessa</a>, <a href="USSR">USSR</a>) is an Israeli <a href="composer">composer</a>. Many of his works have been performed throughout the world. He studied at <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110216075221/http%3A//www.gnesin-academy.ru/index-en.php">Gnessin Music Institute</a> (Academia of Music) in Moscow. Between 1978 and 1990 he lived in Tajikistan, and immigrated to Israel in 1990. In 2002 he received his Ph.D. degree from <a href="http%3A//www1.biu.ac.il/indexE.php">Bar-Ilan University</a> (Israel).
In 1988 he won the special distinction diploma at the International Composers Competition in Budapest for his composition <a href="http%3A//www.pigovat.com/chamber-ensembles.html%23musicadolorosa2">Musica dolorosa No. 2</a> for Trombone quartet.
In 1995 he received an <a href="Society%20of%20Authors%2C%20Composers%20and%20Music%20Publishers%20in%20Israel">ACUM</a> Prize for his composition <a href="http%3A//www.pigovat.com/symphony-orchestra.html%23requiem">Requiem “The Holocaust”</a> for Viola & Symphony Orchestra. The world premiere of Requiem took place at the Memorial evening dedicated to the <a href="Babi%20Yar">Babi Yar</a> tragedy (Kiev, 2.10.2001). It was performed by soloist Rainer Moog (Germany) and <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20100912181916/http%3A//www.filarmonia.com.ua/74">The Symphony Orchestra of the Ukrainian National Philharmonic Society</a>, conducted by <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20081204062319/http%3A//filarmonia.com.ua/78">Roman Kofman</a>. In 2008 it was performed in <a href="Wellington">Wellington</a>, <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>, at the <a href="http%3A//www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0810/S00169.htm">Concert of Remembrance 70th Anniversary of Kristallnacht</a>, by soloist <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110109005748/http%3A//www.massey.ac.nz/~wwnzpq/don.html">Donald Maurice</a> and <a href="Orchestra%20Wellington">Vector Wellington Orchestra</a>, conducted by <a href="http%3A//maximaltd.com/marctaddei/index.htm">Marc Taddei</a>. In 2010, <a href="http%3A//www.atollcd.com/atoll.html">"Atoll"</a> (NZ) has launched a <a href="http%3A//www.atollcd.com/catalog_detail/acd114-requiem-pigovat.htm">Requiem CD</a> with a live recording based on a concert. In addition to Requiem, 3 more compositions were recorded in performance of Donald Maurice and included in the CD: <a href="http%3A//www.pigovat.com/chamber-ensembles.html%23prayer">"PRAYER" for Viola and Piano</a>, <a href="http%3A//www.pigovat.com/chamber-ensembles.html%23thesilentmusic">"The Silent Music" for Viola and Harp</a>, and <a href="http%3A//www.pigovat.com/chamber-ensembles.html%23nigun4">"Nigun" for String Quartet</a>.
In 2000 he received the prize of the Prime Minister of State of Israel.
His composition "Massada" was performed at <a href="http%3A//www.musicweb-international.com/sandh/2000/oct00/worldmusicdays.htm">ISCM "World music days 2000"</a> festival in Luxembourg and at <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110717111830/http%3A//www.wasbe.org/conferences/2003">WASBE 2003 Conference</a> in Jonkoping (Sweden).
The symphonic picture “Wind of Yemen” was performed at the Asian Music Festival 2003 in Tokyo and at <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20101204195651/http%3A//www.wasbe.org/conferences/2009/">WASBE 2009 Conference</a> in <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a> (USA).
In 2005 he received an <a href="Society%20of%20Authors%2C%20Composers%20and%20Music%20Publishers%20in%20Israel">ACUM</a> Prize for his piece <a href="http%3A//www.pigovat.com/symphonic-band.html%23songofthesea">“Song of the Sea”</a>, a poem for Symphonic Band, which was performed in New York’s Carnegie Hall.
Works.
Pigovat composed for symphony and string orchestras, symphonic bands and chamber ensembles, solo and choir. Full list of his compositions can be found <a href="http%3A//www.pigovat.com/symphony-orchestra.html">here</a>.
